column4: Hi, I have a big problem.  COmpiz used to work in 8.04, but now after upgrading to 9.10 it doesnt.  When I run compiz-check, everything's A-OK, but running compiz --replace causes X to restart, and no compiz.  Help please... thanks in advance!
Can you pastebin the output of 'compiz &' from your terminal to pastebin.com?
just a minute
I have to do compiz >> log, otherwise I dont' get it (X is restarted).  coming right up.
In that case, something is wrong with your graphics drivers. Which card do you have as reported by 'lspic|grep VGA'?
http://pastebin.com/d1bb259af
I have heard of people having the same problem with that intel gpu. Something is wrong with the drivers in karmic and it is blacklisted, probably for this reason
I recommend you try with Lucid or Jaunty and file a bug report if the problem persists
is it a driver problem, or is it a compiz problem.  I'm using the 2.4 intel driver to get rid of X freezing.
It is a problem with the intel driver. Compiz is fine.
It's my mom's laptop, she'll scream if I re-install the os one.more.time.  :)
You don't have to reinstall, you can upgrade to lucid after it's released in April
is it possible to use the 8.04 intel driver in 9.10?
Because of the changes in the kernel and user space driver components, I would say not
ok, thanks for your help.  If you can think of anything more, there's a thread going on about this over here:Â http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1309667&page=2

The other thing you can try is upgrading to the latest intel driver user space components, to see if it helps. Maybe you can look into the xorg-edgers repo, though I don't know if it offers intel components
I was looking at that, but am a little apprehensive.  I'll give it a shot though...
any idea why X just restarts instead of freezing or something?  is it some new failsafe?
It probably wont do any more harm than good.. if you do try latest user space components, it might be a good idea to couple it with a latest kernel possibly from ppa repo
I've been looking at this, but it doesn't mention my chipset anywhere...  do you think it's good? http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1130582&highlight=Intel+Corporation+Chipset
also, since the functionality has dissapeared with the upgrade to 9.10, would it come back? wouldn't my hardware, once abandoned, be left forever?
I cannot say. You could ask in #intel-gfx for more info. That guide looks decent, but it is designed for 9.04
ok, thanks@
